Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: To be honest, I went to every lecture and could not keep up in the slightest bit because all she did was read off the slides and her paper, play aimless videos, and read word for word what is on her paper as fast as she could
Helped me to think more critically about the world around me and why certain organizations or people might be taking certain actions.

This class was a brilliant introduction to the study of public health through history. With no background, I was able to come in a walk away understanding many important themes and patterns in public health that have prevailed through the centuries.
History of global health

We were given a comprehensive history of global health and perspectives in global health that helped us to understand how the sociopolitical status of an era can greatly impact the health outcomes of individuals. It was often the case that it was not the disease itself but rather the lack of health system resilience and structural support in the sociopolitical grand scheme that made it difficult to tackle the disease.
I learned how to historically frame current issues.
I learned a lot about health! I really enjoyed the class and the critical lens. The material was really interesting, and you cover from the Colombian exchange to the early 21st century.
This course provided a great overview of key figures/organizations in the history of colonial medicine and international health.
I learned how to write historical arguments, and analyze historical sources.
I developed a more complete view of world history, as well as writing and discussion skills.
I think that I learned a lot about the history of global health generally, as well as the background of modern-day medical practices and global health interventions.
I learned that Global Health is fully a western concept, if not American. Its fully focuses on one of two categories: biosecurity & humanitarianism.
I learned so much about both world history and the history of global health through this semester. The class moved fast, but I am so glad we learned everything that we did.
how to evaluate and read primary sources and develop research skills

I developed a lot of knowledge about global health throughout history from the 15th century to the present. I also developed the skills to critique global health interventions and think about how to intervene in a helpful way.

I learned about what global health was and also its advantages and disadvantages. It was really insightful because it made me consider aspects of global health I otherwise would have never thought about.
I developed an understanding of the fundamental underpinnings of global health and the forces that drive it.
I learned about global health campaigns in the past and the evolution of the current form of global health.

By taking this course, I learned a (most Western) perspective of how global health has changed over time. The lenses of time included the colonial era, both World Wars, and current times. Through section, I also learned about how global health has affected a particular country.
This course gives a broad overview of the history of global health starting with European colonialism and continuing to the present.
Knowledge about global health systems and why they're flawed.

I think the structure of the course material could be improved in terms of making the lectures flow together. I also think the slides could be more informative in terms of containing dates, names, and overall significance of the person/event/place. It was difficult to catch what the professor was saying and take notes, so if these items could be on the lecture slides, the lecture could be easier to follow.

strengths: my TA was amazing and essentially retaught us everything
weaknesses: the class went too fast, lecture was too fast, content was boring and all over the place, never a clear path to what we are learning, spoke in monotone the entire time and couldnt look up from her notes, videos made no sense

Strengths: had the ability to be an extremely interesting class with great material

Weakness: material was confusing as Tess was not a good lecturer and all over the place

Need different perspectives. This class is called historical perspectives (with an "s") but the focus felt very narrow and the narrative was portrayed in the same manner I feel like it always has been.

The strengths in this course are the content, the lectures, and the section discussions. I thought all three were excellent, but I wished we could have engaged with the readings in a more meaningful way.

It was taught horribly. The material was interesting and the sections were taught well but the lectures were very disorganized, lacked engagement, and the professor didn't even make eye contact. she read the entire lecture from a piece of paper very quickly so nobody could take notes or understand what she said. sad because the material is very interesting.

Strengths: the class did much to describe historical blunders in global health and how this history has impacted equity and wellbeing via the creation and maintenance of many of the social, governmental, and economic dterminants of health in the field that we know today. 

Weaknesses: the class time needs to be lengthened from 50 minutes to 75 minutes. I can obviously tell that the reason why Tess lectures through narratives rather than engages on the floor with students is because of how short the class time is on top of it being for only 2days/week. Its unfair to her in that she is greatly limited and unfair to us in that we are not learning as well as we could be. Additionally, the class can benefit from a more diverse host of guest lecturers that are not just academics but health activists and doctors from different places. This is not to discredit academics but rather so that the historical perspectiveS (intentionally capitalizing the S here) can be heard. The historical documents that weve used throughout the class have done well to describe the historical moment and actors in the field but have come at great cost to limiting the voices of the historically oppressed/PoC actors since they did not have as much agency in those periods. This field is starting to change and I among many of my classmates would like to observe this change through the voice of diverse actors on the ground who are changing the landscape through their own involvement. If we are looking for them to be exemplary by not doing what we have historically seen to not work, we shouldnt. We should be able to question them as well based on what weve learned so as to improve student engagement with the material.

lectures were a bit dry
slides were sometimes hard to extract key information from

Strengths: Tess lanzarotta is very kind and cool! The material is very interesting, TAs are nice, section is useful to unpack what happens in lecture. 
Weaknesses: this was the first HSHM class I had taken and I am a stem major, so i sometimes was confused/had a hard time following lectures. I had a hard time differentiating the history/factual part from the critical/perspectives part but that is on me

I really appreciated the critical approach the professor took towards global health, and I learned a lot about the history of American and European imperialism and how that is linked to global health today. I also loved getting assigned a country for the 3 papers as I was able to study another country in more depth than I would have been able to with just one paper. 

The lecture slides and format of the lectures could be improved since the professor often ran out of time at the end or did not clearly convey important concepts + their meanings. It would be useful to add more information about key figures, ideas, and events in history onto the lecture slides rather than just a picture or a few words.

The lectures were very informative and worth attending. The readings were selected well as well. It was evident that the team of TF's put in genuine effort for the success of the students and the course.
The only real problem I had was that the first paper was due very soon after the midterm.

The course covers a lot of material that has the potential to be very interesting. However, the course itself is paced inconsistently. The first half of the course speeds through the eighteenth century, nineteenth century, and Pre-WWII 20th Century, while the second half focuses almost exclusively on Post-WWII history. I understand that the availability of information, as well as content applicable to the course, varies depending on the time period being covered, but it makes it difficult to follow. Moreover, the course itself lacked a clear acknowledgment of the narratives of women and people of color. I understand that it can be difficult to bring to light these narratives, but that's part of the point of a course titled "Historical Perspectives" (note the plural).
weakness: Lectures were very boring just because the professor would read off of her laptop and wasnt engaging

Strengths: I really enjoyed writing the papers. It was interesting to talk to our peers about the medical histories of other countries across the world. 

Weaknesses: It was a lot of work. 3 paper, a midterm, & final.
overall great

I think the strengths of the course were the vast amount of information that offered a broad overview, the use of specific examples, and the papers. The papers were very interesting because you got a specific country and wrote three different papers on the health issues over time in that specific place.

weakness: professor read straight off their laptop so the lectures were very boring and at times they would rush over important parts. The class felt all over the place sometimes and we would jump decades and units in history and then go backwards at points.

I think the structure of the slides during lecture would be improved. It was often difficult to follow and write important details down. Also, while I liked the idea of learning about a new country it would have been better if we could each pick countries we wanted. I think that would have helped make our papers all the more interesting.
The lecture and readings are very good.

The readings are usually very interesting and relevant for the topics of the week. The lectures were very difficult to follow and it felt like the only way to learn anything was by trying to write down as much as possible from what she says and try to piece together the point of the lecture afterward. Also, there wasnt enough structure and clarity with what they expected of our essays. My TA was also a very good section leader and she clearly cared about my success in the course.

One strength of the course was the quality of the discussion sections, which really placed what we discussed in class in a larger, international context. Another strength was being assigned a particular country in order to dive deeper into the global health issues there. One weakness of the course was the mostly monocular perspective in which this class was viewed. Another weakness was the relevance of some of the guest lectures to the course. I feel that making those lectures optional, extra-credit lectures not held during class would have strengthen the important concepts learned towards the end of the class.
Weaknesses some topics are so large that we only touched the surface, but that is the design of the class. The paper structure was helpful and the TAs were really good.

The greatest weakness of the course is Professor Lanzarottas lecturing style: each lecture feels like she is reading off of a script which makes the lectures unengaging and difficult to follow as she uses many big words in the sense that they have larger meanings that would have made more sense had they been qualified or specified.  She makes statements in her lecture that would be excellent in an article but, as she moves through lecture very fast, there is no time to dwell on them.

First 3/4ths of the course had interesting material but the last couple classes were lackluster and didnt have content that flowed well with the early bit of class - could have had a better historical frame.
Lectures are interesting, sections run well.
Personally, I wanted a course that was more chronological and history focused. I would recommend other history courses like Public Health in America, 1793 to present or Media and Medicine.
save yourself and dont take this course. monotone lecturer. you cant type 2 words without her switching the slides.
No, Tess was not good at lecturing making it very difficult to follow allow and stay engaged during lectures.
It wasn't the right class for me, but that doesn't mean there was anything wrong with it. Look at the syllabus and decide if the topics seem interesting enough to you.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. I thought that the topics covered are important for any Yale student to understand, and it covered the subject in a way that is interesting to a STEM student, a humanities student, or anyone who has ever been to a hospital.
Yes
no

This course is great for all students who are studying health (includes pre-meds, HSHM majors, Global Health Scholars, etc.) or remotely interested in health. Health is a multidisciplinary affair and learning about the historical causes/contributing factors to existing inequalities in health and lack of resilience in health systems today is great to all who will encounter problems regarding health in the long run.
Yes! I learned a lot

I would recommend this class if you're interested in global health or simply curious about the field and its history. This class taught really important lessons about the complicated historical roots of global health and made me think about humanitarianism and philanthropy through a more critical lens. The country assignment (writing 3 papers about one assigned country) was also really fun!

I would recommend this course to any of my friends. I already have suggested Historical Perspectives on Global Health as a great humanities credit option for hesitant pre-med friends. The course material is accessible and useful for students with a variety of interests.

The course itself discusses interesting developments, but I would not recommend it. The use of certain jargon limits understanding unless one has taken a prior course in HSHM or Global Health. The pace of the course is inconsistent. But most of all, it just wasn't an engaging lecture.
I would recommend this to any HSHM major or anyone interested in health in general. It definitely changed my perspective on humanitarian campaigns.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It gave me a critical lens through which I will now evaluate my global health and medical work and I am so grateful for it.
Absolutely not
Yes! learned so much and was glad to go to class and section every time.
I would recommend it to another student because overall the readings were pretty interesting and the topics are good to know about.
No, this class was not well organized and you get little no feedback or clear rubric on how to do things better.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. The material learned is fundamental to global health today.

I would recommend this course taken CR/D because it is hard to gauge what the grading will be like and the class isnt taught super well but it has some good content that can be learned. I think this class has potential and there are valuable takeaways from the course but its not worth the time to try and do well.

I would tentatively recommend this class to another student. The class itself is a bit difficult to comprehend the concepts because lectures are full of terms, examples, and concepts that are not known to most students. With so much material, lectures either fly by material or the material is recapped for 15-20 minutes at the beginning of the next lecture. While the majority of lecture focuses on the Western perspective, section shifts those concepts to other perspectives in the world. Be prepared to Google a lot of the words and examples used in class in gain a full understanding.

I would not recommend this course because a lot of the information conveyed seemed rather redundant of other classes, such as Global Health Challenges and Responses and Media and Medicine, which are better taught.
I think also for all Professor Lanzarottas talk of the problems with Euro-centric approaches to global health, the course spends a disproportionate time covering US and European perspectives on global health, while the only non-white person presented in the course as important to global health was Frantz Fanon (who is, of course, incredible).  Furthermore, there are several historical events that Professor Lanzarotta presented as fact or supporting evidence in her argument in class that were quite traumatic, but their significance in this capacity was not addressed - again an issue of not enough voices of the colonized.  
Overall, the class was fine, but I did not end up getting as much out of it as I thought I would.
Yes its informative for people who havent taken global health courses before, otherwise its more of the same. Class has interesting assignments.
less papers
